H0.text: The Sun turned diatoms into oil after 10‑20 years, as the oil used today is made from the ancient remains of these tiny sea creatures that converted sunlight into stored energy while they were alive.

H1.text: Diatoms are the original source of energy for oil, because the oil used today is made from the ancient remains of these tiny sea creatures that converted sunlight into stored energy while they were alive.

H2.text: The Sun is the original source of energy for oil that comes from the ancient remains of tiny sea creatures called Diatoms, which converted sunlight into stored energy when they were alive.

H3.text: Diatoms converted oil into energy is a statement that follows from the fact that the oil used today is made from the ancient remains of tiny sea creatures called diatoms, which, when alive, converted sunlight into stored energy.

A4.text: Abiogenic sources of oil have been found, but never in commercially profitable amounts.

A5.text: Aquatic phytoplankton and zooplankton that died and sedimented in large quantities under anoxic conditions millions of years ago began forming petroleum and natural gas as a result of anaerobic decomposition.

A6.text: Despite these heat-driven transformations, the energy released in combustion is still photosynthetic in origin.

A7.text: but only with the Mesozoic (251–66 Ma) radiations of dinoflagellates, coccolithophorids, and diatoms did the primary production of oxygen in marine shelf waters take modern form.

A8.text: Diatomaceous earth consists of the fossilized remains of diatoms that accumulated over millions of years.

A9.text: Only 1% to 10% of frustules survive long enough to be buried under sediments and some of this is dissolved within the sediments.

A10.text: Diatomaceous earth consists of opaline silica.

A11.text: Diatoms contribute nearly half of the organic material found in the oceans.

A12.text: Anaerobic conditions, the by‑product of this metabolism is the gas methane (CH4).
